title: How to Know How Much Seasoning to Add to Food

steps.headline: Check the recipe if using one.
steps.description: If it does have measurements, use them.

steps.headline: Always add a little and then add more as needed.
steps.description: It is always possible to increase the flavor but much harder to mend a dish that has been over-flavored.

steps.headline: For spices, add 1/4 of a teaspoon for every pound of meat or vegetables or pint of liquid such as a sauce, soup or chowder.
For garlic powder, cayenne pepper and chili, add 1/8 teaspoon for the same amounts.
For fresher flavors such as fresh herbs, add a teaspoon and then gradually increase the amount.
steps.description: If the herbs are dried though, be very careful as they are much stronger and can easily overpower the dish. A quarter teaspoon is a good starting point for most dried herbs.

steps.headline: Test the flavor.
steps.description: Add small amounts more if needed.

text: Check the recipe if using one. If it does have measurements, use them. Always add a little and then add more as needed. It is always possible to increase the flavor but much harder to mend a dish that has been over-flavored. For spices, add 1/4 of a teaspoon for every pound of meat or vegetables or pint of liquid such as a sauce, soup or chowder.  For garlic powder, cayenne pepper and chili, add 1/8 teaspoon for the same amounts.  For fresher flavors such as fresh herbs, add a teaspoon and then gradually increase the amount. If the herbs are dried though, be very careful as they are much stronger and can easily overpower the dish. A quarter teaspoon is a good starting point for most dried herbs. Test the flavor. Add small amounts more if needed.
